title: Let saints below in concert sing

author.name: Charles Wesley
author.bio: Charles Wesley was a leader of the Methodist movement, most widely known for writing over 6,000 hymns. Wesley was born in Epworth, Lincolnshire, England, where his father was rector. He was educated at Christ Church, Oxford, and formed the 'Holy Club' among his fellow students. After an unsuccessful ministry of a year at Savannah in the Georgia Colony, Wesley returned home and joined the religious revival that was led by his brother John Wesley. He became one of the most prolific hymn writers in history, known for his contributions to the Methodist hymnal and for hymns such as 'Hark! The Herald Angels Sing' and 'Love Divine, All Loves Excelling'.

lyrics:
Let Saints on Earth in concert sing
With those whose work is done;
For all the servants of our King
In Heav'n and Earth are one.

One family, we dwelling Him,
One Church, above, beneath;
Though now divided by the stream,
The narrow stream of death.

One army of the living God,
To His command we bow;
Part of the host
Have cross'd the flood,
And part are crossing now.

E'en now to their Eternal Home
There pass some Spirits blest;
While others to the margin come,
Waiting their call to rest.

Jesu, be Thou our constant guide;
Then, when the word is given,
Bid Jordan's narrow stream divide,
And bring us safe to Heav'n.
